results.title: The Black pirate. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Gregstan Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
An edited and narrated presentation of the duels, sea battles and acrobatics in the ‘Black Pirate’ an adventure film made in 1926 starring Douglas Fairbanks. Includes the famous sliding-down-the-sail stunt. Also stars Billie Dove.

results.title: The Black pages
results.brief_description: Stunning yet restrained cinematography is a feature of this beautifully lit work which demonstrates controlled use of colour in a piece employing controlled kinetic movement within the frame. Considered visual composition and a strong soundtrack support an intriguing storyline.

results.title: The Black lake
results.creator_credit: British Foundation Pictures and Ronald Haines
results.brief_description: The famous asphalt lake in Trinidad is the scene of one of the island’s major industries. The film shows how the raw material is dug, processed, packed and shipped to many parts of the world. Trinidad asphalt is used for floors, roofs, electrical insulation and roads. Roads surfaced by Trinidad Lake asphalt are found the world over. The film includes a full account of operations at the asphalt refinery converting the raw material from the lake into the finished product ready for export.

The film includes a full account of operations at the asphalt refinery converting the raw material from the lake into the finished product ready for export.

results.title: The Black death, 1361
results.creator_credit: Leo Eaton, Altug Savasal, Diane Holmes and Maryland Public Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Timeline”.
A dramatic recreation of the social upheaval experienced in the Middle Ages due to the spread of the Black Death. Modelled on a news broadcast, the program looks at the causes and impact of the Plague, and “interviews” key historical figures of the time. At its most virulent, the disease decimated both city and rural populations and created severe labour shortages.

results.title: The Black chain
results.creator_credit: Michael Sklar, Carousel Films, CBS Television Network and Joseph Krumgold
results.brief_description: Significant achievements in streptococcus research and the potential cure of rheumatic heart disease. Filmed at the Alfred I. Du Pont Institute in Wilmington, Delaware, showing the work of Dr Arnine T. Wilson. Microphotography shows the actions of white and red blood cells and the virulent form of streptococcus (Black chain) and the defence of one against the other.

results.title: The Bittersweet tale of Doffy Notts
results.brief_description:
Everyone loves Doffy Notts the clown - he makes you laugh. But hidden beneath the layers of makeup and costume is a very different Doffy Notts - a very sad and lonely Doffy Notts.
A beautifully crafted work using 2D and 3D animation.

results.title: The Birthday present
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Film Australia and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Johnson and friends”.
Johnson, a courageous pink elephant, leads his friends on a series of adventures. He is joined by Alfred, a leaky hot-water bottle, McDuff, a cheeky concertina, Diesel the dump truck and Squeaky the battered robot. The stories on this tape include: “The Birthday present”, “Playing games”, “Sharing”, “The Picnic”, “Windchimes” and “Cleaning day”.

results.title: The Birth of the baroque
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The 17th century interiors of Protestant churches were filled with Baroque art. Congregations were brought to God through the richest and most dramatic use of religious imagery. The architecture, sculpture and painting of the Baroque were designed together, part of a total and individual whole. Vigorous movement embracing the entire facade is also a characteristic of Baroque architecture and Caravaggio is highlighted in this episode.

results.title: The Birth of Soviet cinema
results.creator_credit: Harold Mantell and Maxim Gorky Film Studio Moscow
results.brief_description: Examines the golden age of cinema in Russia in the 1920’s by presenting excerpts from masterworks of Eisenstein, Pudovkin and Dovzhenko by film critic Richard Schickel. Explains why the 1920’s was a productive time for cinema in general.

results.title: The Birth of New China = Kai Guo Da Dian
results.creator_credit: Changchun Film Studio, Li Qiankuan and Xiao Guiyun
results.brief_description:
This is a detailed retelling of the events leading up to and following the Communists’ triumph in the Chinese Civil War (1945-1949), from the perspective of the two leaders of the contending parties. Although there is a distinct agenda in the narrative, the film attempts to display an objective point of view, examining quite closely the human strengths and flaws of the leaders of both sides. While the film takes a distinct moral position, there is a distinct shift in narrative approach from films of the pre-Cultural Revolution period.

Jiang Kai-Shek, leader of the Kuomintang (Nationalist) party is shown to be a worthy adversary to Chairman Mao Zedong. The Nationalists have so far outgunned and outmanned the Communists. All the Reds have going for them is the support and respect of the common people, what Mao calls “the heart and soul of China”. Jiang ends up being defeated and flees to Taiwan, vowing to return and crush Mao.

On February 3, 1949, Communist army enters Beiping, where Mao gives his famous speech (the original footage is shown in part). Meanwhile, Jiang laments his defeat, explaining in hindsight how the Kuomintang overthrew itself. The sore point of the film for the Mainland Chinese is the so-called “stripping of wealth and treasures” from China, transporting them overseas to Taiwan. This was an epic operation, with shiploads of gold and cultural treasures being secretly transported to Taiwan over the final months of the war.
Celebrating the 40th Birthday of the People’s Republic of China (1949)
(3 stars: James Donald; June 10, 2011)
